DEBATE.TITLE: ABSENCE OF PRESIDENT AND DEPUTY PRESIDENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Clerk-Honourable senators, the President and Deputy President are unavoidably absent at this time. In accordance with standing order 30 the Senate may proceed to elect a senator to act as President.
That Senator Colston take the Chair of the Senate to act as President this day until such time as the Deputy President is available to take the chair.
The ACTING PRESIDENT (Senator Colston) thereupon took the chair, and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilisation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 150 citizens), Richardson (from 164 citizens) and Vallentine (from 105 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Hawke Government's intentions to impose a tax on fringe benefits and so increase the level of taxation in Australia, will impose an unnecessary and harsh burden on many companies, a burden that could have an adverse effect on employment.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Hawke Government will abandon this unfair and potentially job destructive tax and your petitioners as in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer- submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chipp (from 72 citizens) and Zakharov (from 36 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention of the Elmination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that ``States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women''.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26.1.85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the articles of the Convention and requests the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Lewis (from 38 citizens), Missen (from 490 citizens) and Zakharov (from 243 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Belconnen Mall, Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
We the undersigned express our concern over the sale of the Belconnen Mall due to the likely detrimental effect on the provision of community facilities presently existing in the Belconnen Mall.

1. In particular we seek guarantees that the present Child Care Centre and Community Facilities be retained by incorporating the same into the conditions of sale of the Belconnen Mall and that the services will receive the same real level of funding and support currently provided by the Canberra Commercial Development authority.

2. That a financial commitment to the Building of Stage 4 of the Belconnen Mall listed under section 14C in the Ordinance of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority be undertaken. Stage 4 to consist of community facilities such as community hall, large glassed enclosed community park, exhibition space, health and fitness club, ice rink, amusement centre and office accommodation.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this petition be considered.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows: That we urge that the Australian Government expresses its concern to Indonesia over consistent reports of widespread human rights violations in East Timor, as detailed by Amnesty International, and that the Indonesian Government be urged to take steps to prevent killings, torture and arbitrary arrest and imprisonment, as has been recently reported.

We would further humbly request that the Australian government use its voice at the United Nations to lobby strongly for the reinsertion of East Timor to the Human Rights Commission Agenda; that the above human rights concerns be raised at the General Assembly when the Decolonization Committee makes its report; and that steps be taken to initiate UN conducted negotions between Indonesia, Portugal and representatives of the East Timorese people, including Fretilin.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud:
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
i. a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
ii. subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
iii. farmer unrest at seed prices,
iv. monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
v. increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to notice which I gave yesterday, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent paragraph (2) of this Resolution having effect.
(2) That the Question on the matter of urgency moved by Senator Durack under Standing Order 64 on 6 November 1985 be put forthwith.
That motion was:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need to strengthen Australia's alliance with the United States through an effective ANZUS Treaty and the maintenance of joint defence facilities.

The Senate will recall that the two hours for consideration of that urgency motion expired before any vote was taken and that, as a result of that, immediately it expired I moved for the suspension of Standing Orders to enable that motion to be put and a vote taken forthwith, on Wednesday afternoon, 6 November. Unfortunately, that motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, although supported by a very clear majority of senators, did not satisfy the requirement of Standing Orders that it should have an absolute majority of senators; I think that it was one short of that. As a result of that, I gave this notice of motion yesterday so that the matter could be rectified and a vote could be taken. That is why I have moved this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the Senate that I may have many faults but the incapacity to count is not one of them. For that reason, it would be pointless for us to divide on such a motion, although we may oppose it. I just wish to say that on Wednesday, from my reading of the Hansard-I was not present at the time-the simple reason for Senator Gareth Evans and the Government opposing the motion was that the urgency motion itself was put up as a party political act, not an unusual thing to happen in this chamber, and it was considered necessary to demonstrate that this was so. It was considered necessary to demonstrate in both the debate and the vote that that was so, and that was done quite clearly. Senator Durack has since used a tactic that I would have used, and has moved for the suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders so that he no longer needs an absolute majority of the Senate. He quite clearly has a simple majority of the Senate to carry this motion and for that reason we will not oppose it.

SPEECH.PARA: With the indulgence of the Senate I might just say that when the vote is taken the Government will support the urgency motion for two simple reasons. The first is that it is Australian Labor Party policy to favour an effective ANZUS Treaty. It has been stated many times by the Government that it would like to see an effective ANZUS Treaty, a Treaty that is more realistic, and one which has New Zealand in it, and therefore we cannot oppose that section of the motion. Secondly, we are willing as a government, and have said so-it is our Party policy-to host the joint defence facilities for their early warning and verification roles; we are not particularly happy to host them for their war fighting capacity. But, in light of the fact that the motion simply says `the maintenance of joint defence facilities', we cannot be hypocritical and not support the motion in that regard.

That does not mean that we think that the moving of motions like this assists the American-Australian alliance any more than we think that the attitude of some members of the United States Government, as expressed in some of their actions and remarks, assists this alliance. A couple of weeks ago I represented the Australian Labor Party at a disarmament conference in Vienna. I and members of other social democratic and democratic socialist parties and governments in the world pointed out that we were in alliance with the United States, that we had such an alliance for historic and obvious political and defence purposes at the moment but that at the same time we wished to be treated as partners in such an alliance and not in the manner in which, one may say, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics sometimes treats its partners in alliance. All I can say is that at that conference a senior representative of the United States treated those of us in this alliance situation in much the manner that the USSR treats its alliance members. I do not believe that that representative did so necessarily with the approval of the United States Government or the United States President.

Despite that, we still support ANZUS and we still support the maintenance of the joint defence facilities, because if we are to have disarmament we need verification and early warning systems. For that reason we will support this obviously party political urgency motion, but I repeat that breast-beating of this type by Opposition parties and attempts to enter into debates on delicate matters of foreign policy and defence in this way do not advance the cause of this country. It may help the warm inner glow of some people opposite, particularly some of those who will vote against the motion, but it does not help this country's relationship with the United States or anybody else. Having put that position, I think it would be fairly sensible, after a few more people have got up and done a bit more breast-beating, to get on with the vote that inevitably will occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Briefly in reply, I hope that the Senate will be able to take an early vote, and I do not want to delay the Senate on the matter. I simply cannot let some of the remarks of the Acting Leader of the Government, Senator Grimes, go without comment. The fact is that the security of our nation is the most important responsibility for this Parliament and this Senate to consider. The motion put forward by the Opposition on Wednesday afternoon reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need to strengthen Australia's alliance with the United States through an effective ANZUS Treaty and the maintenance of joint defence facilities.

Back bench members of the Australian Labor Party are now coming out in their true colours. Most of them do not like this. They adopted the most extraordinary tactic of squibbing the issue by voting against the motion which their Acting Leader, Senator Grimes, has this morning decided they should support. That is why the Opposition moved this motion; not for the political tactics or reasons that Senator Grimes has suggested. I hope we will now be able to have a vote on this and let those members of the back bench of the Labor Party show us whether they do or do not support the rhetoric of their Prime Minister.

We do not operate in that way. The reason there was no vote on Wednesday was that the Opposition added an extra speaker and talked the time out. DEBATE.TITLE: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT BILL 1985INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 November, on motion by Senator Hamer:

That the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill 1985 be referred to the Standing Committee on National Resources for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in February 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a motion moved by my colleague Senator Hamer, that the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill 1985 be referred to the Standing Committee on National Resources for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in February 1986. In the absence of other honourable senators wishing to speak on this motion, Senator Hamer has asked me to speak on his behalf and to make the remarks he would have wished to make at the conclusion of the debate on his motion. As the Senate is aware, Senator Hamer, in his capacity as Deputy President, is fulfilling certain formal functions relating to the royal visit this morning and therefore he is unable to conclude the debate on his own motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is debating a motion moved by Senator Hamer under Standing Order No. 196A. It states:

That the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Bill 1985 be referred to the Standing Committee on National Resources for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in February 1986.

The motion has been moved because the Bills are obviously defective-a position which has been accepted by the Australian Democrats, who have planned to move a substantial number of amendments in the Committee stage. There have been claims of insufficient consultation with large sections of the industry; there are problems with the regulations which, it is claimed, are too general and too broad; the agreements with the States are not yet finalised; and the Inter-State Commission is producing a report on cost recovery for interstate road and rail services. These are serious defects which will not easily be corrected. There is no hurry for these Bills. They cannot be proclaimed before the middle of next year at the earliest. In the view of the Opposition, they are perfect examples of the sorts of Bills which should be referred to a Senate legislative committee for public examination. Opposition members of the Standing Committee on National Resources are confident that such consideration could be completed by the first sitting day of February 1986.

What is the alternative to referring these Bills to the Standing Committee? It is that we immediately go into the Committee of the Whole here where we are unable to have any of the experts and the people affected by the legislation. Senator Vigor has heard representations from some individuals and has done a deal with the Government to get these amendments accepted. But are these amendments all that is necessary? Even more, do not the amendments proposed create new problems, which people affected might be able to point out to us? I do not know, but I am sure of one thing-the Australian Democrats do not know either. It seems to me an irresponsible and totally unnecessary action to rush these Bills through the Senate when there is a standing committee set up to consider legislation in detail and when the result of such consideration would undoubtedly result in better Bills than we could produce by rushing them through the Senate today.

The only argument that Senator Vigor of the Australian Democrats produced in favour of rushing the Bills through was that this would encourage the States to pass the essential complementary legislation. I do not believe that the passage of these Bills by this Parliament would affect by even one day the date on which the States would pass their legislation. The agreement to pass complementary legislation is already in place and the States would be encouraged rather than discouraged if this Parliament properly considered this legislation before passing it. There is no urgency whatever for us to pass these Bills. Early next session would provide a generous margin for implementation. I urge the Government and the Australian Democrats-I shall come back to the twisting and conniving of the Australian Democrats to avoid their own party policy on this matter-to think again and refer this Bill to a Senate legislative committee for proper examination, for proper input from experts and for thorough and proper input from those people in the road transport industry whose livelihoods depend on our getting this legislation right.

I would like to deal with one other point. During the earlier discussion of this motion the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, interjected: `This is just another delaying tactic'. It is nothing of the sort. I suppose that, in a sense, every minute given by the Parliament to consideration of Bills is a delay. The bureaucrats and the Executive would like Parliament to be a mere rubber stamp for their proposal. Nevertheless, we have a duty, as the legislature and as the elected representatives, to see that Bills are properly examined, always bearing in mind, of course, the necessity for timely enactment of the legislation. Timeliness is not a problem with this Bill. The Government is planning or hoping to push something like 67 Bills through this Senate before we rise in December. There is no way we can give proper consideration to these Bills without using our supporting committee system which was designed to make our consideration of Bills more effective.

The Opposition has been through the Government's proposed legislative program and a committee consisting of Senator Hamer, Senator Peter Rae and myself has examined this in detail and has listed 19 Bills which, in our opinion, would benefit from being publicly examined by a Senate committee and which could afford to wait until early next year for passage through the Senate. I am sure that everyone who has served on a Senate committee examining a Bill would agree that the result of such examination is a much better Bill than that which was originally produced. It is our duty to produce proper legislation, not to rush Bills through in a frantic panic in the last and late nights of a session. Therefore, as each of these 19 Bills comes up we will be moving to refer it to an appropriate committee. I repeat to Senator Vigor, through you, Mr Acting President, for we are looking for support from his party for the proper examination of Bills, that this is not a delaying tactic. It is part of our duty to ensure that legislation is properly drawn and to ensure that this Parliament does not accidentally or unwittingly make mistakes which would affect the lives or livelihoods of people whom we are supposed to be elected to serve.

The debate on this matter has gone on for some time. It will be recalled that, in terms of the motion originally moved last May by Senator Chaney and referred to again by Senator Hamer in his remarks, if our proposals had been accepted this debate would have been curtailed to 30 minutes and that would not have left us open to the accusation of wasting time.

I want to draw Senator Vigor's attention to a document which he may never have seen. It is entitled `Australian Democrats Policy Papers-Part 3'. I presume that Senator Vigor has never had the benefit of studying this document. Therefore I propose, through you, Mr Acting President, to enlighten him as to what the formal policy of his own party is in this regard. On page 8, under the heading `Parliamentary Reform' and the sub-heading `Joint Parliamentary Standing Committees', the document states:
Surveillance by Parliament of the Executive and of public administration should be strengthened by the establishment of a powerful committee system.

All government activity should be open to scrutiny by committees, which should also assist Parliament by making members more aware of matters which need to be dealt with. Committees will also provide a specific mechanism to ensure due consideration of any matter brought before Parliament . . .

The document goes on to state that there should be ample time for this study. Let me take Senator Vigor to page 9 of this policy document. Under the heading `Policy Items' and the sub-heading `Legislation' paragraph 6 states:
While a Bill is before Parliament it will be scrutinised, clause by clause, including any delegations of power, by the relevant Standing Committee.

Here we have the Australian Democrats-the proponents of the political principle of keeping the bastards honest. On this occasion we will be able to test which of the Australian Democrats-I hesitate to use their own terminology-will be found honest in this matter. Here are the policy papers of the Australian Democrats. Here is a clear statement that while a Bill is before Parliament it will be scrutinised clause by clause, including any delegation of power by the relevant standing committee.

On this particular matter the Democrats apparently are in the process of refining hypocrisy into an art form and, indeed, their political twistings on this matter would make any cork-screw look like a ramrod. We have, therefore, the opportunity to put it squarely to the Australian Democrats. They keep telling us that the important thing in Parliament and in parliamentary legislation is that we should adhere to the principles upon which we were elected and that we should take our Party platforms and work for their implementation. Here, for the first time in the course of this session, is a motion moved which is 100 per cent in accordance with the formal policy statement of the Australian Democrats. On the first occasion that they are asked to adhere to their own printed document, to their own formal policy, they are about to squib, they are about to rat and they are about to betray. They are once again about to demonstrate the value of the word as given in policy statements of the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —That word `scrutinise' is a bit big for them.

—Indeed. I happen to have had the great advantage of hearing Senator Macklin on the radio on the PM program on 6 November. He was discussing the Bill which he has before the Parliament about democratic elections. He was discussing why it was necessary to bring that into the Senate for debate and why he expected the Australian Labor Party to support it. As I was listening I wrote down his exact words. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We must make sure the Labor Party abides by its own policy.

All we are doing is asking the Australian Democrats to abide by their own policy. Here they come into the chamber and castigate the poor members of the Australian Labor Party and say: `All we want to do, members of the Government, is to invite you to abide by your own policy'. I say to our colleagues in the Australian Democrats in moving this motion: All we invite you to do is abide by your own policy. We are perfectly happy to judge the integrity of the Australian Democrats as a political force in this chamber by measuring them, not against our tests, but simply against the tests which they erect for themselves and put forward in their own policy documents.

As I have said, the motion moved by Senator Hamer is part of a campaign upon which the members of the Opposition will be embarked between now and the end of this session and well into the next session. That process is to identify those Bills coming before the Parliament which clearly require some additional parliamentary scrutiny before they are debated in this chamber or before they are considered in the Committee of the Whole. We have identified, as I said, 19 pieces of legislation which ought to be subject to that. We will be moving precisely this motion on each occasion that one of those 19 pieces of legislation comes before us for consideration. We will watch, wait and see what the Australian Democrats do about this. One thing which is not in doubt is that these two pieces of legislation require further amendment. The Democrats have recognised that by seeking to move amendments or to give notice of lengthy, detailed and complex amendments in the Committee of the Whole.

At the moment the Democrats are rushing around the countryside attempting to drum up support for all sorts of propositions, to tell us that in fact they regard this as a matter of great moment. I am reminded that Senator Vigor has a proposition before the Senate that there ought to be an additional select committee, one specificially to deal with the question of transport because he regards this as so important and urgent a matter and the sort of thing that ought to be considered. We agree that it ought to be considered. We agree that there are many people unhappy with the legislation. We do not necessarily have to go out to those people and ask them to send us telegrams telling us what a good job we are doing on their behalf. We know full well that we will be judged on our actions in this matter. Those who have an interest in seeing this legislation properly debated and improved will be grateful, without our soliciting them for telegrams of support to boost our egos and to remind us what good fellows we are in the course of this debate.

We have not given assurances, as Senator Vanstone so cogently pointed out the other evening in reference to the assurances given by Senator Vigor to various public meetings around the place, that the legislation will be delayed until 1 December or that some crummy, under the table or behind the chair deal will be done with the Government to get this amendment accepted as a trade-off for passage by this particular date. We do not happen to believe in legislation by covert deal. We happen to believe in legislation by public examination; we happen to believe that legislation ought to be examined in full light of public scrutiny, public debate and public participation through use of the Senate committee system. It is not our proposition that government and, in particular, members of minor opposition parties, should get together and cobble together some covert deal, saying: `Give me these amendments and I will give you the Bill by such and such a date so that we can make electoral heroes of ourselves'. We happen to have far higher standards than that.

I once thought the Australian Democrats had far higher standards than that. I was one of these naive people who actually believed that when the Australian Democrats put something in their formal platform and in their policy statements they might actually be persuaded once in a while to adhere to it. I thought that in terms of keeping the bastards honest that was going to be a touchstone of permanent value for the Senate. I now find that honesty is a tradeable commodity, that honesty is a commodity which can be bargained away as far as deals done with the Government are concerned.

If anything, this debate has served two useful purposes: First, it will allow us to determine whether in fact the Democrats have a genuine commitment to the Senate committee system; secondly, it will allow us to determine whether the Democrats have any commitment to their own policy statements. We will be able to judge and to weigh them on that basis. We are not asking for a delay which will unnecessarily hamper or prevent the passage of this legislation, or indeed will in any way interfere with the States passing the necessary complementary legislation to give effect to the overall package. We are saying that these Bills are defective. The issue is important. The Senate has the expertise and the resources to be able to do something about it. What it needs on this occasion, because of the balance of votes in this chamber, is the commitment of the Australian Democrats to see the Senate committees work, see the Senate committee system expanded and used in the way that it ought to be and to see the two pieces of interstate road transport legislation examined, reported upon and improved prior to their passage, which could then be facilitated in the early part of the session in 1986. We will watch, we will judge and we will see on this occasion just how honest the `bastards' really are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the second attempt being made by the Opposition to delay this legislation. In the debate that took place on the legislation last Tuesday an attempt was made by the Opposition to delay it. Now we have the assurance of Senator Puplick that that is not the intention. Nevertheless, the motion we are debating today-incidentally, it was moved after the conclusion of the second reading debate, taking advantage of a standing order-seeks to have this legislation referred to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. It is a rather hollow tactic on the part of the Opposition to prevent the Senate in a four-day sitting from passing one piece of legislation. This will be due substantially to the tactics the Opposition has adopted during this sitting week.

SPEECH.PARA: It is just not true to say that inadequate or unfair consultation has taken place in respect of this legislation. For the past two years the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), in his inimitable style of seeking views, and compromise where views cannot be accepted, from the States and other interested parties, has brought down a fast track package of legislation which will have the effect of substantially meeting the needs of the industry. The legislation was formulated on the basis of extensive consultation with all the major political parties ensconced in the State parliamentary area. It is a tribute to the Minister that he has been able to reach substantial agreement with National Party, Liberal Party and Labor Party governments because not even within the Labor Party is there necessarily a common position on matters affecting Commonwealth jurisdiction on which there are State views and which involve States' rights. This legislation was debated at length in the House of Representatives some weeks ago. It is wrong to suggest that somehow or other the legislation which has come into this place does not represent the consensus and the compromise approach which has been the objective of the Government in respect of the legislation, knowing full well that the introduction of legislation that does not have the support of the States and cannot, therefore, be portrayed as representing a genuine view in respect of State attitudes means that its passage in the Senate will be rather torrid.

Senator Puplick, who was forced to carry a brief at short notice, spent half his time denigrating or attempting to embarrass the Australian Democrats. He put up a pretty implausible argument as to why the legislation should be put aside. It is clear that the Opposition has no coherence on this matter. In the debate that has taken place on these two pieces of legislation affecting the national attitude to our fast track industry, the important road transport industry, most of the Opposition senators said that they supported the legislation and its general thrust. Yet, when it comes to the nitty gritty of dealing with this matter in a cogent and sensible fashion, Senator Puplick seeks support for a part time amendment to refer the legislation to a committee. This would achieve the same objectives as the amendment that was defeated in the Senate on Tuesday night. That is why Senator Puplick has spent so much of his time, not debating the logic or illogic of the Opposition's policy attitude to the legislation, but rather attempting to make some sort of an impassioned plea to the Democrats to change their view as expressed in the vote on Tuesday night and vote for the amendment which, if accepted by the Senate, would probably mean that no legislation at all would be passed in this sitting week.

The Government has the responsibility of governing. In this session it has brought down these two pieces of legislation to meet that objective. A committee was set up which reported to the Parliament in September 1984. Since that time the Minister has spent countless hours as, indeed, have his officers, in travelling throughout Australia talking to the leaders of the industry and the States and coming to a conclusion which will have to be accepted. This conclusion was reached in a spirit of compromise; nevertheless it met the basic thrust and the basic responsibility of a national government to produce a piece of legislation that would establish some measure of influence, control and jurisdiction in respect of the road transport industry. Since this legislation was being discussed in the House of Representatives we have had correspondence, telexes and other indications from the States of support for the general principles of the legislation. On 17 September, Mr Hinze, the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Racing, said in a telex:
Given the constitutional realities, and the complexities of other alternatives Queensland agrees that the Commonwealth Government should implement the type of scheme proposed.
He then went on to say:
Generally, there has been good co-operation between Commonwealth and State officials working out the administrative details of the scheme.
One Labor Minister, the Western Australian Minister for Transport, in a letter of 21 October-that was after the House of Representatives had passed the legislation and referred it to the Senate-said:
My Government accepts that the Commonwealth is acting in good faith with this legislation, for the benefit of the States.
Of course, the gem of them all is the statement of the Tasmanian Premier, Mr Gray, made on 20 October 1985 in a welcoming speech to the Australian Road Transport Federation. He said:
My Government has expressed its support for the fast track package . . . and is currently working on means of implementing those recommendations requiring State Government action.

One is therefore entitled to ask what is the Opposition's strategy and what are the problems for the Opposition? Is it that the Opposition, having said in debate that it generally supports the legislation, is taking the delaying, obstructionist tactics which have been a feature not all the time but from time to time of the tactics of the Opposition in the Senate when we have had Federal Labor governments? It is just not true to say that somehow or other the Government is acting improperly or that it is not acting in concert with the States. It is also not true to say that it does not have the substantial support of the industry itself.

Listening to the debate on this legislation one could come to the only conclusion that the Government is faced with an Opposition that is playing an obstructionist role. For example, in the debate on Tuesday the Opposition moved an amendment to the motion for the second readings, and that was defeated. The Opposition then indicated that in the Committee stage it would move 50 amendments which were clearly designed to bog the Senate down and to create difficulties in the passage of this legislation. Will we be confronted with that action, assuming that the Senate does not agree with the new tactic that has obviously been thought out by the Opposition front bench? Will the Senate be put in such a position whereby, the Opposition having taken the opportunity to move an amendment at the second reading stage-I appreciate that that is a definite tactic-it will be bogged down with 50 amendments from the Opposition?

There have been discussions with the Opposition and with the Australian Democrats. A measure of goodwill and co-operation has been extended by the Minister in the way in which he has operated not only in this place but also in discussions that took place with the industry and with State representatives. We concede that it is not always possible to accommodate everything that is asked for when there is a conflict of views, but the Government believes that the legislation is a reasonable compromise. Therefore, any suggestion that some fast track tactic is involved, that we are trying to prevent the Senate from exercising its review responsibilities and that somehow or other we are denying the normal and logical debate processes on this legislation, falls down completely because there is no evidence to suggest that the Government's approach to this matter is not fair and reason- able. It is just an example of the democratic rights of sections of the industry to present another viewpoint.

Who do we accept represents the viewpoint of the industry? One small group that is very vocal has a right to present its view to government, the Opposition and to any other person involved in the debate on the issue. We concede that. Nevertheless, the Government has set itself the responsibility of having this legislation passed so that we can begin the process that Mr Gray suggested, that is, the process of complementary legislation which has to flow from State jurisdictions.

We know that the passage of this legislation does not mean that as from Monday next, for example, all things will fall into place and another area of consultation with the States will take place as they begin the process of bringing in their complementary legislation. That is the way in which governments and Ministers should operate when we have to deal with six States. We should have consultation with not only the States but also the Territories. We are attempting to establish some form of uniformity in road safety standards; we are attempting to establish a package which will protect the interests of the operator, particularly the small operator. He may not see it that way. Nevertheless, that is the strategy of the Government and that is the strategy that everybody associated with the industry accepts is fundamental if we are to bring about a cogent and coherent policy in respect of the road transport industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech made by Senator Puplick before that of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) was an interesting one. Obviously he had sifted his way through Roget's Thesaurus in order to come up with the colourful language that he used and weave it into one short speech. The unfortunate thing about it is that it is a Johnny-come-lately speech on this whole operation. He is obviously totally unaware of the negotiations that have been going on with his Party with regard to the reference of Bills to committees. It is a pity that a range of items about not engaging in any discussions or activities was not recorded in Hansard because that is precisely what his front bench and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) have been doing with us. I suppose one cannot blame him, having been fed in with very little briefing, for trampling over the area on which his front bench colleagues have been walking.

SPEECH.PARA: I will simply rehearse, in brief-I do not wish to hold up or contribute in any way to the Opposition filibuster on this matter-that the proposition of sending Bills to a committee for scrutiny and report is one with which we have indicated we agree in principle. We have done that by letter and publicly and we hold to that proposition. However, we have said that we saw in that proposal, which was basically the proposal put forward in a notice of motion by Senator Chaney and debated some time ago, a range of practical difficulties. I will enumerate some of those difficulties which were encompassed in a letter sent to the people who were negotiating this matter on behalf of the Opposition parties. Since it was a letter I was invited to write to a particular person, I do not intend reading it because I assume that that would be seen to be confidential information.

I will refer to the seven basic problems we saw. One was that it was suggested that we agree to allowing a debate of 30 minutes for every item. We have already seen this operating today. Since six or seven items are sometimes placed on the Notice Paper to agree to that proposition by way of sessional order would decrease the debating time on legislation by some three hours a day. Since on most debating days we do not manage to get three hours of debate on Bills, it would mean that no government legislation would proceed at all.

The second problem relates to references to committees in the numbers that have been indicated by Senator Hamer in his notice of motion earlier this week, an extract of which appears in the motion which we are currently debating. We raise objections to that based on the time for the standing committees to meet, have a hearing and produce a report, and the staff resources which would be able to be provided for that. On a one-off basis those types of problems do not occur, but we are not talking about a one-off basis here. If we refer to the 19 Bills which are the subject of the proposition before us, we see that we are talking about a massive hike. We will find in a debate later in this chamber on the Appropriation Bills that we will have to make some fairly hard decisions about how the resources available to this chamber are allocated.

The third proposition is that the standing committees need to be augmented. Senator Vigor has drawn attention to one hiatus and other honourable senators have drawn attention to other parts which are missing from our standing committees which would prevent a comprehensive coverage of all legislation.

The fourth problem is that the sittings of the Senate would need to be changed radically to accommodate such operations. We already know that this chamber sits for fewer days than most comparable chambers around the world. Unless honourable senators are willing to reduce the number of days we sit, finding additional time for senators to appear on those committees will be somewhat difficult. I draw attention to the fact that senators often serve on more than one committee; the average is sometimes three or four committees. That applies to almost every senator in this place, particularly with the recent addition of two select committees.

The fifth problem relates to implications in terms of Hansard reporting staff, particularly if, as has been projected, a number of committees meet at the same time. Only a certain number of Estimates committees can meet at the same time, so that the idea of every standing committee meeting at the same time, plus some of our select committees, is simply not feasible at the moment.

Sixthly, there is evidence before the Senate that the establishment of the Estimates committees to investigate in a detailed manner the subject matter of the Appropriation Bills so that the Committee of the Whole-Senator Puplick referred to this-need not go on as long as one might otherwise have thought has failed. Since 1979 the average time spent in Committee on Appropriation Bills, after all the Estimates committees have dealt with them, is 16 1/2 debating hours, which is just over a week of the Senate's sitting time. That is more than the amount of time it used to take before the Estimates committees operated, so we are looking not at a decrease in the time which the chamber will sit if we do more committee work, but an increase. We would welcome that, but every honourable senator ought to know what it is about and the decision ought to be made by every honourable senator, not just those in the Opposition parties.

Seventhly, the parallels which have been drawn between the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and reference of Bills to committees are totally fallacious. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee operates on a quasi-objective basis, whereas sending Bills to a standing committee, fairly obviously, is a political operation. That is fair enough and we would agree with that. I remind Senator Puplick, because he was not here at the time, that every time we moved for a reference to a committee the Fraser Government kicked and screamed blue murder. Every time it resisted to a vote sending any Bill to a committee. So let us not have the pompous type of moralising from Senator Puplick, which really does not befit the type of proposition he is talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to the Freedom of Information Bill?

—Senator Puplick has already spoken. If he wants to get up and speak again, he can seek leave. The proposition which Senator Puplick was asking us to accept went way beyond that which Senator Hamer was asking us to accept. Senator Puplick's proposition was that any Bill which the Opposition feels should be sent to a committee should be so sent to a committee.
—No, that is not our view.

—That is what Senator Puplick said. The difficulty with that proposition is that the normal method by which this chamber sends Bills to a committee is in fact by a majority of this chamber voting to send those Bills to a committee. We do not want to subscribe to the minority running this place.
—That is a great line, coming from the Democrats.

—I invite Senator Puplick to look at the Hansard to see whether at any time a decision made here was not made by a majority. The proposition to which Senator Puplick referred related to the necessity for some Bills to be scrutinised by a committee. We have wholeheartedly accepted that proposal in the past and will continue to do so in the future. Indeed, we have already indicated an attraction to the proposition of more Bills being sent to committees. When the Liberal and National parties were in government they would have resisted valiantly any attempt to have this proposition imposed on them, as it were, in one fell swoop. We have proposed that any such proposition should be given to the Government. We have said that at some period in the future, when the Government has reorganised its legislative program, we propose to support a proposition to send more Bills to committees. I think that is the way to do it. That is a reasonable proposition, which, if Senator Puplick were sitting on the other side of the chamber, I am sure he would support.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats are attempting to be fair to the Government's program as it is currently brought forward and also to be fair to increasing the scrutiny which this chamber is able to provide. I think that is a laudable objective. Other proposals have been put forward. For example, it has been suggested that we do away with most of our second reading debates and increase the amount of time that would thus be released for more detailed debate in the Committee of the Whole. That seems to me to be an interesting suggestion that would be worth while entertaining and debating. We have suggested that this proposal ought to be examined by a committee. We think there is a logic in that. If one feels so strongly about the committee system, one should not be resisting an inquiry into that proposal. However, we find resistance from the Opposition parties to having the proposed changes in this chamber examined by a committee. It seems a very odd situation. We feel that a committee inquiring into the legitimate and worthwhile proposals that have been brought forward probably would come up with some new proposals by which this chamber may be able to proceed with its business.

In conclusion, I bring to the attention of the Senate that currently, before the House of Representatives meets next week, on the Senate Notice Paper we have 60 Bills. This week we have already spent eight hours discussing so-called matters of public importance and we will discuss such a matter again today. As I have said on other occasions, when one looks at how important the matters of public importance are, one feels that the Government of this country cannot be dealt with evenly by the Senate or the House of Representatives if the Senate feels that many of those matters are so urgent and important that they have to be debated today, having been debated last week, the week before and the week before that.

What we would urge now is a Committee of the Whole debate. We have prepared complex amendments-yes, Senator Puplick, they are complex. They have been circulated to honourable senators and to the Opposition shadow Minister and doubtless have been the subject of investigation within the Opposition's party structure. We believe that these are the amendments which are needed finally to bring together the Bill as it is. It is not a difficult Bill; it is not a complicated Bill; it is a fairly straightforward Bill. It is one which has been debated for a fair amount of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you say it was? Good heavens!

—I am sorry if Senator Archer finds it too complicated; but then, he might find the ABC complicated. If he wants to have a look at a complicated Bill, I suggest that he come in when we discuss the Veterans' Entitlements Bill, with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) in the House. He would then see what a complicated Bill looks like. This is a relatively straightforward Bill. It is a very important Bill; I am not denying that. One would hope that the debate that we will be able to have in the Committee of the Whole will be sufficient to reform the Bill in a way which I think will be acceptable to the majority of honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay this Bill but I rise briefly. I feel it necessary to be rather less charitable to Senator Puplick than was my colleague, Senator Macklin, who is perhaps of a kinder and more generous disposition than I am. Senator Puplick's speech was facile, but much less than honest. I do not blame him for that. That was basically because the total Liberal-National Party enterprise which is now under way is much less than honest. Senator Puplick made a specific attack on the Australian Democrats, saying that we have policies in certain directions and that he felt we should abide by them. Australian Democrat policy covers a huge ambit of action, which would indeed, if it came into legislative form, transform Australia into a modern and prosperous democracy. Meanwhile, however, we have to live with the real and far from ideal world of today's politics. Senator Puplick knows that just as well as I do. As Senator Puplick generously conceded to us, we have to carry out our task of keeping the bastards honest. It is not always easy, but we do our best one way and another.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in this place yesterday, the Government has continued to resist-and has given clear notice through the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, that it will continue to resist-giving this Senate the financial means, the staff and the facilities to carry out its committee functions properly. I am hoping very much that as we get further into considering the recommendation of Estimates Committee A to us, the Liberal Party will follow what Senator Puplick is saying and not sell him out, because unless the Opposition passes that resolution of Estimates Committee A as it stands, the Opposition will be much less than honest itself. I am saying this in the interests of keeping the Opposition honest. Think about it for a while. Of course the Democrats would like to see every Bill referred to a committee; of course we would like to do these things that Senator Puplick has said. I will just leave these words in the minds of Opposition senators, and we will see what happens by next week. The real fact of the matter is that this is a political ploy on the part of the Opposition. There is apparently, I gather-and we have our sources of information-the strongest desire in certain States, especially South Australia but possibly also Tasmania and Western Australia, where, believe it or not, there will soon be State elections, not to have this legislation passed for a while because it is felt that it might be the sort of legislation that rocks the boat where a minority group is concerned; to wit, the truckies. I suggest that this is really the reason behind what the Opposition is doing, and the Opposition is being less than honest in not admitting it. Perhaps Senator Messner will get up and admit it. I am sure we will have triumphed if that ever happens, but somehow I doubt that it will.

My next point is that we have a vast amount of legislation before us still to get through. We are getting well towards the end of this session of Parliament. We have not done all that much this week. I do not think we have passed even a single Bill this week, largely due to the fact that every day the Opposition has put up quite inane and repetitive matters of public importance, which has been done before over and over again. Opposition senators know as well as I do that they like to pull the old speech out of the drawer; it is much easier if they can bring up an old subject again because they do not have to go to the trouble of writing a new speech. I think it is getting a little bit tedious one way and another that they do this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you spoken on them?

—I have not spoken on a matter of public importance this week, not once. I have not and I would not do so, because the Government has told us that it has a lot of Bills it wants to get through which it considers necessary to the good government of this country. The Democrats have taken a pledge not to unreasonably block, delay or interfere with government legislation, except for the best of reasons. Things being what they are, we, in close consultation with the community and the interest groups concerned, make that decision. We have made such decisions before and we will make them again. Whether we want it or not, that happens to be our responsibility, and we are not shuffling it off on the Opposition's behalf. In our judgment, this is not such a case. There is not a good reason for putting this Bill to a committee and delaying it. I am very concerned at what is looking very much like a filibuster on the part of the Opposition, and the Opposition knows perfectly well what our attitude towards filibusters is. We hold our hand over the Opposition and we allow Opposition senators the right to speak. Without us they would not get it; they could be gagged and guillotined every day. We give the Opposition that right, but it is up to us to decide when the Opposition is being naughty and it is being naughty now. I suggest, my little friends, that you might stop doing that.
—`Admonish' is the word.

—I have a reason for saying that and it is this. What are we playing with here? I want to get this back into its proper proportions. We are playing with a matter of the life and death of Australians on the road every day. Opposition senators know as well as I do that, if they delay this Bill, that will create a significant number of deaths which would otherwise probably have been avoided.
—Oh, what rubbish!

—Wait a minute, Senator Puplick. The purpose of this Bill is to so regulate truck traffic on Australian roads as to make them less amenable to accidents. Senator Puplick knows that as well as I do, and I suggest he consult his conscience on it. If we delay this Bill, it will be at the cost of the safety and lives of Australians using the roads. We know perfectly well that most truckies are good, respectable drivers. Some of them are not. It is those ones who are not that we are trying to get at. Everybody who drives a car in this country has had an unpleasant experience with a truck on the road. To some of them that unpleasant experience has meant being a paraplegic for the rest of their lives, a long stay in hospital, or being killed. That is not good enough for the Australian Democrats. We will not tolerate the Opposition playing political games on this basis.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, from experience the Opposition knows what our attitude is towards filibustering. I only hope that this filibuster will not continue into the Committee stage of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am provoked by the unrestrained hypocrisy of Senator Mason to stand and at least address some of my remarks to this outrageous display of misbehaviour on the part of the Australian Democrats when the Liberal Party is taking such a principled position in referring to a committee a Bill of very great controversy and very great concern to the Australian community. I am drawn even more by looking at the Notice Paper and noting that Senator Vigor himself, in a notice of motion on 23 August this year, has already moved for the creation of a Senate Committee on Transport. Surely the Democrats, with Senator Vigor's leadership in this, are clearly interested in investigating further the question of road transport in this country, and its relationship with rail transport and so on. Yet they stand in this place and want to push through legislation which has demonstrable opposition from the State governments and are now trying to act against the interests of the State parliaments in terms of what they might have to say on these matters. Senator Vigor until just now has been leading the debate on this matter, but I notice that other senators have had to take it out of his hands because he is simply too much of an embarrassment to the Democrats, having already put down this notice of motion on the Notice Paper. Clearly, that is a very difficult and tricky position for the Democrats to be in at this time, when one of their members is saying `We ought to refer matters of transport to a committee of the Senate to investigate the whole matter' while Senator Mason and other Democrat senators are saying: `We ought to push the Bill through as quickly as possible'. If anybody is confused it has to be the Democrats. What about the Democrats, for once, standing up in this place and giving us their honest opinion about what is right for this country, instead of playing politics with every little piece of influence in the community in the way that they do. SPEECH.PARA: I have two simple questions for the Government on this matter. It seems to me that some quite significant points have not really been explained. Why is it that we have to rush this legislation through the Federal Parliament at this time when it will not have effect before 1 July 1986 and when the States must pass complementary legislation before that time and there are some six or eight months for that to happen? Why is it that we have to push this through now?

TALK.START.PARA: —So that the States can respond.

—Why is it that the Federal Parliament has to take the lead in this matter and why is it that it has to push this matter through now when the States have not, through their parliaments, expressed a view on it? It smacks of some kind of jack-booted approach by the Federal Government-which is typical, of course, of the Hawke Labor Government-in trying to press its opinions upon the States. SPEECH.PARA: The second question is simply this: Even though the essence of this legislation is the imposition of a registration fee of, I understand, $1,400 on interstate registered vehicles, there is also to be, concurrent with that, a requirement that vehicles have a monitoring device attached. If that be so, why is it necessary, bearing in mind that the Government is charging a flat registration fee, to impose an alternative method of taxation? TALK.START.PARA: —You are evading the question. Why don't you get on to the motion?
—I am just raising these points of principle at this stage in the hope that the Government might be able to answer them and so short circuit the debate at a later stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments on the referral of the interstate road transport Bills to the Standing Committee on National Resources will be brief. Senator Puplick talked about the Australian Democrats not supporting the referral of legislation or other matters to committees. In all fairness, I have found the Democrats, particularly Senator Mason and Senator Vigor, very attentive to committees and in the Senate standing committee system I have developed with them a very good working relationship. I find that they are very attentive at committee meetings and they are very attentive to various matters raised in committees. Seeking to refer this matter to a committee is just a delaying tactic by the Liberal Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: If one goes back and looks at the history of the legislation and at the committee that was set up-I know this has been said but I think it needs to be said again-one finds that the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry, which comprised the Chairman, Mr Tom May, Professor Gordon Mills and Jim Scully, commenced in 1983 and reported in September 1984. The Government responded to it in 1984, and subsequently in June 1985 the recommendations were endorsed by the committee itself. The report and the fast track package which subsequently eventuated have received broad industry and general community support. In other words, it has been discussed by the industry itself, it has been discussed by the operators and by other people within the industry, and they have agreed to it. So it seems to me that referring this legislation to a committee is only a delaying tactic by the Opposition. At this stage having a committee look at something, which has already been looked at, or making recommendations so that legislation can be brought up in this place is not warranted.

Senator Messner said that it looked as though the Government was adopting some sort of jack-boot approach, that we were forcing the legislation through and were not discussing the matter with the State governments. If one looks at the report of the inquiry that was undertaken one finds that there was discussion with the Australian Transport Advisory Council, which comprises Federal, State and Territory Ministers. I think it lays out very clearly the fact that there was discussion with State Ministers and their departmental officers in relation to the legislation that has been brought forward. I think it is important to the industry that this legislation goes through this place so that we can, as Senator Mason said, create a position of safety in relation to it and also bring some sort of organisation and regulation into this industry that for so long has been unable to manage its affairs in the way it should have managed them or meet the requirements that have been placed upon it.

All I can say is that trying to force this motion through is a delaying tactic by the Opposition. There has been an inquiry and there has been long discussion with people involved in the industry and with Ministers who hold the transport portfolios within the States. Because of the discussions held and the recommendations made, I believe that this legislation should be supported in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to the reason for the debate taking place today. It arises out of your contingent notice of motion, Mr Deputy President. Before I do that I have to correct something I said earlier. When this matter was debated on Wednesday I referred to vehicles thundering along the Hume Highway, apparently with 26 wheels. I have been advised that that is not right, that they normally have 22 wheels not 26, and that they do not cart 40 tonnes but gross 38 tonnes in the eastern States and 41.9 tonnes in South Australia. I apologise for those errors in what I said on Wednesday night. Nevertheless, I can assure you that if one is passed by a 22-wheeler grossing 38 tonnes, travelling at about 75 miles an hour, it is quite a frightening experience.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to debate the issue of the referral of the interstate road transport Bills to a Senate committee and the merits of that because I really believe that it has been proved beyond any shadow of doubt by my colleagues that this legislation is in such a shambles that it ought to be referred to a Senate committee. I want to raise the higher ground. As you know, Mr Deputy President, this all arises out of a notice of motion which has been sitting on the books since 10 May this year. It is notice of motion No. 25, given by Senator Chaney, and it seeks to install forever the legislative purpose of this chamber. I honestly direct my remarks to the back benchers of the Australian Labor Party. I want them to think about the Senate chamber and its purpose. This is clearly the legislative House. This is where legislation gets looked at in some detail and where it is amended. The legislation cannot be amended in the House of Representatives unless something sudden and drastic happens to the Government, in which case there would probably be an election. But it can be amended, whether we are in government or the Australian Labor Party is in government, by the Senate, which is the House which amends legislation. For that reason the Senate has set up a number of standing committees to look at various pieces of legislation. The first such committee it set up in 1932. It is the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which considers how subordinate legislation should be dealt with. It then set up the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to look at the same sorts of things as are considered by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and to report on those matters to the Senate.

Senator Chaney has put down this notice of motion which, if passed, would enable Bills such as these Bills to go to a Senate committee for proper examination. It is well known that when legislation goes to a bipartisan Senate committee it comes out with proper and adequate amendments, usually unanimously supported by the members of the committee. I know that it was your idea, Mr Deputy President, when you put down your contingent notice of motion that, where there is legislation which ought to be referred to a Senate committee, a motion could be moved that would enable a Senate committee to give proper and adequate consideration to it. If ever legislation needed proper and adequate consideration by a Senate standing committee, it is this legislation.

As my colleague Senator Messner has mentioned, Senator Vigor of the Australian Democrats has already indicated that there ought to be a Senate committee on transport and communications to consider the very sorts of things that are raised by these Bills. I cannot understand why the Democrats are being so blockheaded about supporting this proposal. It has not yet been accepted by the States. Even the Federal Government is operating on the basis that the earliest this legislation could operate by is 1 July next year. There is therefore all the time in the world for a bipartisan Senate committee to give this legislation adequate and proper consideration and report to the Senate as to whether it adequately fullfils the tasks which the Government is suggesting in the second reading speech it should. I hope that the Democrats have had second thoughts about this matter and are prepared to support the Opposition on it.

As to the general question, I hope that back bench Labor senators will apply their minds to the enormous benefits to the nation of Senator Chaney's proposal. It is a bipartisan and impartial proposal. There are no party politics in notice of motion No. 25 because it is anticipated that one of these days we will be back in government and the situation will continue; in other words, that legislation from the Liberal and National parties will be able to be referred to a Senate standing committee for proper examination. I can assure Government senators that when we were in government a number of our back benchers tried to persuade our Government to adopt this idea but they were unsuccessful. I am hoping that the people opposite who in those days would have supported such a proposition might, as the ALP is in government, support it. This will be to the benefit of all Australians for many years.

This is not in any way an attack on the Government. As I have said, if we can make sure that the legislation which is passed by the Australian Parliament is proper and adequate legislation which fulfils the ideals which the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) expects of it and which are indicated in his second reading speech, it will benefit all Australians. Of course, the Government will not support this proposal because it never wants ordinary senators and members of parliament to have a good look at its legislation as they always find out there is something wrong with it. The Ministers always adopt the Yes Minister principle and say that whatever they and their public servants have drawn up has to be accepted by the Parliament. I suggest the back bench members of the ALP have a good look at notice of motion No. 25 put down by Senator Chaney and realise the benefits in it. I also ask the Democrats to have second thoughts about this matter.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hamer's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Committee to deal first with the Interstate Road Transport Bill 1985? As there is no objection, that is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case any other impression is being put around by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), the Australian Democrats or anyone else, I would point out that the Opposition does support the concept of this matter and so do the States, but there is a lot of difference between what the Minister refers to as supporting the concept and supporting the legislation. What the Tasmanian Premier did was to say that he supported the inquiry and its results. SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's second reading speech makes a tremendous amount of the Inter-State Commission inquiry and its findings, when they come; it talks a lot about the questions of cost recovery; it discusses an Australian road freight transport advisory council; it talks about agreements with the States-but not one of those items is listed in any way in the legislation. I am finding it difficult to ascertain how the matters raised in the Minister's speech will be dealt with in the actual legislation. The second reading speech makes much of these items, but there is nothing about them in the Bill in any way. I would like the Minister to be able to relate how matters of such importance in the second reading speech and other speeches by the Minister can be related to the legislation. If these matters of considerable importance alluded to by the Minister and mentioned so often are not in the legislation, what recourse is there on either the industry or the States to ensure that the undertakings he was giving at the time can be carried out? If the Minister is unable to advise me on that, I guess Senator Vigor will be able to do so because it obviously satisfies him.

Clause 34 of the Bill outlines Federal legislation to cover what clearly are already State matters. These matters of safety, speed limits and graduated licences can all be dealt with under existing State legislation. All I can say is that if these matters are deemed to be important by the States, they either already have legislation to cover them, or they have the capacity to produce legislation to cover them accordingly if they still need them. TALK.START.PARA: —Filibustering.

—No, this is no filibuster; let the honourable senator tell me about cost recovery. The cost recovery question is totally inadequately explained. For a start, nobody has said how much is to be raised. This is a money-making piece of legislation. How much money does the Government intend to raise by way of this legislation? There is no formula on how the amount to be recovered is to be ascertained. The Bill says that the costs are to be recovered. It does not say that the costs are to be recovered to the extent of 10 per cent, or 20 per cent, or 50 per cent, or 75 per cent; it says the costs are to be recovered. Who determines the figure of the damage to the roads? What is the formula for this? What is the formula for the distribution? What is the damage to the roads now?
